overview: The purpose of this Act is to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the second and fifth circuits, which is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. [3] The bill also requires the third circuit of the judiciary and big island drug court to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a women's court pilot program in the third circuit. [3] The pilot program shall implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [3]
appropriations: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii an unspecified sum for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum for fiscal year 2026-2027 to the judiciary for equipment, mental health services, and temporary positions. [3] Another appropriation of an unspecified sum is made from general revenues for the same fiscal years to the department of health for the pilot program and the establishment of temporary positions. [3] The Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs respectfully requests the Committee on Finance to consider an appropriation amount of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) to the Department of Health. [4]
assumptions_and_methodology: The measure is based on Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, which established a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the first circuit known as Mohala Wahine. [3] The Department of Health's requested budget of $801,802 (HB727_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_.PDF.txt) is based on the Department’s staffing requirements for the operation of the existing Women’s Court pilot project of the First Circuit. [2] The Judiciary noted that for a program to be successful, it requires sufficient funding and positions, and a good prospect of recruiting qualified staff. [2]
agency_impact: There shall be established within the second and fifth circuits of the judiciary the women's court pilot program. [3] The bill establishes an unspecified number of temporary positions within the Judiciary and the Department of Health. [4] The third circuit of the judiciary and big island drug court are required to conduct an interim study and submit a report of findings and recommendations to the legislature. [3]
economic_impact: The legislature finds that there has been a significant increase in the number of women in Hawaii jails and prisons over the past forty years. [3] The program's goal is to divert participants from incarceration, support their success in the community, and reduce recidivism. [3] Women offenders face unique barriers to success after incarceration, including being primary caregivers for young children, having lower educational attainment, and lacking a stable work history. [3]
policy_impact: This measure amends the original bill by deleting language that would have established a three-year women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit of the Judiciary. [4] Instead, it requires the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to study and submit a report on establishing such a program. [4] The Act's effective date has been changed to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion, and it will be repealed on June 30, 2028. [3]
revenue_sources: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii an unspecified sum for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the judiciary. [3] A separate appropriation is made from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii to the department of health for the same fiscal years. [3] These sums shall be expended by the judiciary and the department of health, respectively. [3]
six_year_fiscal_implications: This Act establishes a three-year pilot program intended to operate from fiscal year 2025-2026 through fiscal year 2027-2028. [3] It appropriates unspecified sums from the general fund to the Judiciary and the Department of Health for fiscal years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027. [3] The Committee on Finance is requested to consider an appropriation of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) to the Department of Health. [4] This request includes funds for a temporary clinical psychologist position at $145,000 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt), a temporary social worker position at $76,788 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt), and a temporary social services assistant position at $45,216 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt). [4] An unspecified number of temporary positions are to be established in the Judiciary. [4] The Judiciary must submit annual reports to the legislature for the regular sessions of 2026, 2027, and 2028. [3] The third circuit is required to submit a report on its study, including resource requirements, prior to the 2026 legislative session. [3] These reports will include recommendations as to whether the pilot program should continue, expand, or be discontinued. [3] The Act has a repeal date of June 30, 2028. [3] The effective date of July 1, 3000, indicates that financial details are subject to further discussion. [4]
operating_revenue_impact: The appropriations for this measure are from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [3] No impact on operating revenues is specified in the bill. [3] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary and the department of health for the purposes of this Act. [3]
capital_expenditure_impact: An unspecified amount is appropriated to the Judiciary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and fiscal year 2026-2027 for equipment, among other costs. [3] The specific sum for equipment is not detailed in the bill. [3] No other capital expenditures are outlined. [3]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: This Act shall be repealed on June 30, 2028. [3] The judiciary’s reports to the legislature will include recommendations as to whether the women's court pilot program should continue as a pilot program, expand, provide additional services, or be discontinued. [3] Any fiscal implications beyond the pilot period are contingent on future legislation. [3]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The scope of the pilot program has been amended from the second, third, and fifth circuits to only the second and fifth circuits. [4] The third circuit is now required to conduct an interim study and submit a report on establishing a women's court pilot program, rather than implementing one. [4] The appropriation structure has changed from a single appropriation to the Judiciary to two separate, unspecified appropriations for the Judiciary and the Department of Health. [3] A committee report now requests that the Committee on Finance consider an appropriation of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) specifically for the Department of Health. [4] The bill's effective date has been changed from July 1, 2025 to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion. [4]
